Physics in Phyco (Tutorial)¶

Just wanna build¶

Currently Phyco development is focused on dynamics and is able to offer a flexible physics simulation now. But there’s still a few thing you need to know in advance.

To start a simulation you need to create a sim, for example: create sim s. But this simply won’t work because creating sim requires at least one obj (this is the real object in physics).

So the right way to start your simulation is to firstly create your object then simulation

create obj a mass=1
create sim s [a]
start s 1

For your convinience, Phyco can automatically separate statements by semicolon. The above code is equivalent to create obj a mass=1;create sim s [a];start s 1.

The above code runs without exceptions, but returns you lots of zeroes. Let’s just dive into what actually it does.

create obj a creates an object called “a”. This is the minimum format of create, since no parameter more than mass is provided. Though you didn’t provide much info about it, Phyco had to initialize the object to have position, velocity, etc. For those default values, you can check On Specific Class. You may also get why Phyco gives you lotta 0s.

The next command constructs a sim called “s” with objects [a] which you’ve just created. You’re supposed to know that every sim must consists at least one object and objects must be in list (that is, be contained in a pair of brackets []).

The last line starts the sim called “s”. As Newton’s first law supposed, nothing moves, sure would Phyco give you a lot of 0.

Why not get it run¶

Anyway, moving objects is the one that makes a Physics Engine solid and easily you can make your things move. There’re ways to make them move. Physically, you can move a object if you give it force, of any type, if at rest:

create sim s [a] field={field(*[0,-g,0])}.

This indeed looks complex, but really not that much. Let’s examine it part by part. The first few words create sim s [a] is exactly same as before, which construct a sim for you. The next block you have an parameter called field passed to create.

You may think that the asterisk there would really be a eyesore. But when you look in the way you can define field, you find that normally you should pass at least two parameters to it. If you’re intersted, refer to Terms and special syntaxes. But now we’re just keep on our track. Literally from g, you know that we’ve just created the uniform gravity field in the space. Then you type start s 1, you’ve see the object undergoes a free fall.

Not exciting?¶

One object is just so boring. You just create as much as you want (massive creating might be included new version), and just make them collides violently!

create obj a mass=10 initv=vector(100,0,0)
create obj b mass=1 initPos=vector(10)
create sim s [a,b] step=10**-3
start s 0.2

BOOM!
